The problem with an organism-as=
-a-city analogy is that ultimately the genes that encode the organism shoul=
dn't care about how many cells there are in the resultant organism, or how =
long those cells live. The genes (what are ultimately replicated) don't dir=
ectly benefit from those factors.

A selfish gene interested in its own pro=
pagation benefits only on the 'organism' level: The organism is but a vehic=
le for genes' replication. That is, an organism with 1000 cells doesn't hav=
e any innate advantage over one with 100 cells if both replicate at the sam=
e rate (although in fact usually the 1000 cell organism, because it has mor=
e cells, will usually replicate slower and require more resources in order =
to do so). However, niches only reachable or most conducive to multicellula=
rity (like the niche we inhabit) will support multicellular life even thoug=
h their method of replication is both circuitous and inefficient (creates 1=
000 cells to yield a single cycle of replication, which is possible with on=
ly one cell).

I agree that more cells may allow for greater division of la=
bor and ultimately greater capabilities. In nature, though, these greater c=
apabilities generally reduce replicator efficiency and increase environment=
al dependence. Although you suggest multicellularity makes us more robust t=
o change, and certainly some adaptations increase our flexibility (human-le=
vel intelligence, opposable thumbs), the niche exploited by most animals is=
 pretty fragile compared to that of bacteria. 

Bacteria as a whole survive=
 in more diverse environments than animals (e.g. extremophiles that live in=
 volcanos or in extremely acidic conditions), and seem more robust to envir=
onmental changes than more complex organisms (e.g. humans are able to extin=
guish all sorts of mammals without even really trying to, yet struggle to v=
anquish the simple HIV virus). Given a nuclear war, I would think bacteria =
would be in the least danger of extinction.

 Such models did not require simulating human-level intelligence or modelli=
ng different aspects of a car engine, but abstracted away most of these det=
ails. The problem would not be tractable otherwise. This model distinguishe=
s what factors are important (everyone simply tries to minimize time to get=
 to where they are going based on the local information available to them) =
vs. unimportant (simulating a human brain, the proportion of diesel cars to=
 those using gasoline, etc.). While it may appear simple in retrospect, per=
haps many people thought more detailed models would initially be necessary.=
 I think our understanding of natural evolution has not yet isolated the fu=
ndamental vs incidental factors resulting in interesting open-ended complex=
ity growth.

I'm not sure if you are suggesting that there are some deep hi=
dden feature of natural evolution (i.e. external guidance) or that there is=
 a drive towards greater *evolvability* in natural evolution, i.e. the abil=
ity of an organism to further evolve. A more evolvable organism exploits it=
s evolved genetic architecture and developmental process to better funnel r=
andom mutation into a greater range of viable phenotypic variation. 

If it=
 is the latter, then I agree that evolvability may be an important factor i=
n how evolution is able to discover astonishingly complex artifacts. I too =
hope that we can discover the underlying mechanisms behind natural evolutio=
n's creativity, and harness those principles by applying them in a domain-i=
ndependent way.
